result.markdown: --- title: "\U0001F5FA Maps" subtitle: "Maps" abstract: "Geospatial Data and how to use it with intent" author: "Arvind Venkatadri" date: 15 Aug 2022 date-modified: "2023-03-12" order: 70 image: preview.jpg image-alt: Photo by at infinity on Unsplash categories: - Spatial Data - Maps - Static - Interactive - Choropleth Maps - Bubble Plots - Cartograms --- # {{< fa folder-open >}} Slides and Tutorials | Spatial Data in R   | Orange Tutorial | Static Maps  | Interactive Maps | |------------------|-------------------|------------------|------------------| # {{< iconify noto-v1 package >}} Setting up R Packages ::: {.cell hash='spatial_cache/html/setup_cf875c13ad73e8894f6e0abd57168610'} ```{.r .cell-code} knitr::opts_chunk$set(echo = TRUE) library(tidyverse) library(sf) library(tmap) library(osmdata) library(osmplotr) library(leaflet) library(mapview) ``` ::: # {{< iconify openmoji japanese-symbol-for-beginner >}} Introduction First; let us watch a short, noisy video on maps: {{< video https://youtu.be/YH2sAbXv7p4 >}} ## What kind of maps will we make? We will first understand the structure of spatial data and where to find it. For now, we will deal with **vector** spatial data; the discussion on **raster** data will be dealt with in another future module. We will get hands-on with making maps, both static and interactive. ### Choropleth Map What does choropleth[^1] mean? And what kind of information could this map represent? ### Bubble Map What information could this map below represent? Let us now look at the slides. Then we will understand how the R packages `sf`, `tmap` work to create maps, using data downloadable into R using `osmdata` and `osmplotr`. We will also make interactive maps with `leaflet` and `mapview`; `tmap` is also capable of creating interactive maps. ## Your Turn ### Animal and Bird Migration - Head off to [movebank.org](https://www.movebank.org/cms/movebank-main). Look at a few species of interest and choose one. - Download the data ( **ESRI Shapefile**). Note: You will get a .zip file with a good many files in it. Save **all** of them, but read only the `.shp` file into R and Orange. - Import that into R using `sf_read()` - See how you can plot locations, tracks and colour by species....based on the data you download. - For tutorial info: ### UFO Sightings Here is a UFO Sighting dataset, containing location and text descriptions. ### Sales Data from kaggle Head off to [Kaggle](https://www.kaggle.com/) and search for `Geographical Sales` related data. Make both static and interactive maps with this data. Justify your decisions for type of map. # References 1. [Hadley Wickham](http://hadley.nz/), [Danielle Navarro](https://djnavarro.net/), and [Thomas Lin Pedersen](https://www.data-imaginist.com/), *ggplot2: Elegant Graphics for Data Analysis* 2. Emine Fidan, [Guide to Creating Interactive Maps in R](https://bookdown.org/eneminef/DRR_Bookdown/) 3. Nikita Voevodin, [R, Not the Best Practices](https://bookdown.org/voevodin_nv/R_Not_the_Best_Practices/maps.html) [^1]: Etymology. **From Ancient Greek χώρα (khṓra, "location") + πλῆθος (plêthos, "a great number") + English map**. First proposed in 1938 by American geographer John Kirtland Wright to mean "quantity in area," although maps of the type have been used since the early 19th century.
